Thanks for the comments, everyone. Some of these are good ideas
that we won't get to for 1.0, but will keep on the docket for
later.

kaisa_kaunonen wrote:
> Hi all,
> 
> good ideas you have, here are a couple of comments =>
> 
> It's not possible to tell from file names which job each arc file 
> comes from?

Not automatically: it depends on the operator choosing an ARC name
prefix that correlates with the Heritrix job name.

I don't think we want to force these to be the same. The job
names get a formulaic (timestamp) expansion for UI convenience
and uniqueness within the application's domain. However, the
naming needs for long-term ARC file archival may be different and
thus can be chosen in separate ARC name options.

Job names should definitely go into the in-ARC header record;
I'll make that a clear part of the arc-header spec.

> During harvesting every job has its own directory but in the end one 
> may place all arcs into a bigger pool for further processing. 
> 
> Would a series number be unique only inside a job so you could have 
> files
> 
> name - 00001 - timestamp1 - IP.arc.gz
> name - 00001 - timestamp2 - IP.arc.gz
> name - 00001-  timestamp3 - IP.arc.gz
> name - 00001 - timestamp4 - IP.arc.gz
> 
> produced by four different jobs. I somehow think a running series 
> number in an archive implies that no two files in an archive have 
> identical s-numbers (even if their timestamps differ)

The serial numbers are strictly within a single crawl/job for now.
Attempting uniqueness over a larger domain would require other
coordination between jobs, software runs, software installs, etc.

It is currently up to the operator to vary the prefix-names on
subsequent runs in such a situation. If they don't, the above
is possible, which is a potential source of confusion with both
the grouping you show, and when you consider that the default
sort order of the ARCs of separate crawls will be...

name - 00001 - timestamp1 - IP.arc.gz
name - 00001 - timestamp3 - IP.arc.gz
name - 00001-  timestamp5 - IP.arc.gz
name - 00001 - timestamp7 - IP.arc.gz
name - 00002 - timestamp2 - IP.arc.gz
name - 00002 - timestamp4 - IP.arc.gz
name - 00002-  timestamp6 - IP.arc.gz
name - 00002 - timestamp8 - IP.arc.gz

Because of this, we've decided to keep the timestamp and serial-number
values in the current code's order, timestamp first, then serial-number,
so that within a given 'name', the lexicographic sort order will always
match the time-sort order.

> S-number makes file names more unique but it's not very informative. 

We find the serial numbers helpful as a way to highlight a
particular ARC as the container of a resource of interest.
For example, "you can grep for the weird server response in ARC
#27". The timestamps are somewhat more difficult to use as
casual pointers.

> Would it be possible to use job name instead 
> 
> OperatorGivenName - Jobname - Timestamp - IP.arc.gz for example =>
> 
> finland - photoarchives - timestamp - IP.arc.gz
> 
> Slight problem of course that job names have variable lengths unlike 
> s-numbers.

I suspect many operators will want to make their ARC prefixes
and jobnames match, but for the reasons listed above, I'd
rather not enforce that relationship in software.

Some other ideas for the future:
  - an operator could be offered a easy way (checkbox?) to
    make the ARC prefix conform to the job name
  - an operator could be warned if a arc-prefix was used
    in a known previous crawl, and offered a suggested
    revision
  - the crawler could consult an external inventory process
    somewhere to verify that a proposed crawl name and
    ARC prefix are unique

Andrew Boyko wrote:
# The ARC naming proposal sounds good to me.  The only thing I might
# ponder is the idea of a separate identifier, for the instance of a
# repeated crawl.   Obviously the operator could just add a suffix to the
# 'operator-given-name', and the timestamp is a clear key to regularly
# repeated crawls (monthly or weekly), so this isn't a big deal.  Even so,
# it's still compelling to have the tool auto-generate a sequence number
# whenever a operator-given-name is reused within an instance of the tool.
#  Two or three digits would presumably more than cover it.
#
# So in the example of repeated Congress crawls (to choose an example at
# random :), assuming the same instance of the tool is used for each, the
# seventh ARC for the fifth instance of the crawl would be
#    CONGRESS005-00007-20040420133907-FG71E2B.arc.gz
# where the 005 is automatically assigned by the crawler based on the
# prior instances it knows of, and of course defaults to 001 for any new
# crawl name.

We've been relying on operator diligence to do this, and picking date-related
names -- things like CONGRESS0312 (dec 2003), CONGRESS0401 (jan 2004), etc.

I agree automating this would be a big operator convenience For the current
update, though, we'll leave this as a manual practice rather than rush in
an automated system that might be constraining.

# As far as the new header block, why not add the entire crawl order and
# seed list?  A couple K added to a 100MB file shouldn't worry anyone.

Excellent point. It might also be achieved as a special record
past the header; perhaps even as a crawler self-fetch, like...

   http://127.0.0.1:8080/currentcrawl/order.xml

It might be sufficient to do this only for the first ARC, or otherwise
include this info by reference where preferred by the operator.

- Gordon @ IA
